categories.name: Spending & Contracts
categories.description: Questions about how the council spends public money

templates.title: Liberata UK Ltd Contract
templates.why: Liberata UK Ltd is Pendle's largest supplier at over £54 million total spend. This contract covers core services including revenues, benefits, and customer contact.
templates.template:
Dear FOI Officer,

Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I request the following information regarding the council's contract with Liberata UK Ltd:

1. The full contract value and duration (original start and end dates)
2. All contract extensions or variations agreed since the original contract was signed, with the financial value of each
3. The current annual contract cost and a breakdown of services covered
4. Key performance indicators (KPIs) and the most recent performance report
5. Any penalty clauses in the contract and whether penalties have been applied in the last 3 years
6. The cost comparison analysis (if any) between outsourced delivery via Liberata and in-house provision
7. Whether the council has considered bringing any Liberata-delivered services back in-house, in light of Burnley Council's decision to do so
templates.context: Liberata UK Ltd has received over £54 million from Pendle Borough Council. Burnley Council (£36.7M to Liberata) has announced plans to bring services back in-house. Understanding Pendle's contract terms helps residents assess whether the council is getting value for money.

templates.title: Homelessness and Temporary Accommodation Costs
templates.why: Pendle's homelessness costs have reportedly increased by over 5,000% in recent years. Understanding the drivers and costs is critical for accountability.
templates.template:
Dear FOI Officer,

Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I request the following information regarding homelessness:

1. The total annual expenditure on homelessness services and temporary accommodation for each financial year from 2019/20 to 2024/25
2. The number of households in temporary accommodation as at 31 March each year
3. The average weekly cost per household in temporary accommodation, broken down by type
4. The total amount spent on bed and breakfast or hotel accommodation for homeless households each year
5. A list of all providers of temporary accommodation used by the council, with amounts paid to each
6. Whether any homeless households have been placed outside the Pendle borough
7. The council's Homelessness Prevention Strategy and reports on its effectiveness
templates.context: Pendle's homelessness costs have reportedly increased dramatically. This is one of the fastest-growing areas of council expenditure nationally.

templates.title: PEARL Joint Venture Governance and Finances
templates.why: PEARL is a joint venture between the council and a private partner for regeneration. Understanding governance and financial performance helps assess whether public money is properly managed.
templates.template:
Dear FOI Officer,

Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I request the following information regarding the PEARL joint venture:

1. The PEARL partnership agreement or shareholders' agreement (or a summary if commercially sensitive)
2. The total public investment committed to PEARL since formation
3. Annual financial statements or management accounts for PEARL for each year since formation
4. Details of all properties or land transferred to or acquired by PEARL
5. The governance structure including board membership and decision-making authority
6. Any independent reviews or value-for-money assessments of PEARL
7. The profit-sharing or return arrangements between the council and private partner
8. Any exit provisions for the council to leave the joint venture
templates.context: Joint ventures between councils and private companies have been controversial nationally, with concerns about governance, transparency, and whether they truly deliver value for taxpayers.

categories.name: Governance & Accountability
categories.description: Questions about how decisions are made and who is accountable

templates.title: External Audit Disclaimer and Financial Controls
templates.why: Pendle's most recent external audit resulted in a disclaimer of opinion — the most serious audit outcome possible, meaning the auditor could not confirm whether the accounts are accurate.
templates.template:
Dear FOI Officer,

Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I request the following information regarding the council's financial audit:

1. The external auditor's management letters (ISA 260 reports) for 2022/23 and 2023/24
2. The specific reasons given by the auditor for issuing a disclaimer of opinion
3. The council's formal response or action plan addressing the issues raised
4. All internal audit reports completed during 2022/23, 2023/24 and 2024/25, or a list with titles, dates, and assurance ratings
5. Any correspondence between the council and the external auditor regarding the disclaimer
6. The current status and expected completion date for the 2024/25 accounts and audit
7. The fees paid to the external auditor for each of the last three financial years
templates.context: A disclaimer of opinion is the most serious outcome of a financial audit. It means the auditor was unable to obtain sufficient evidence to form a view on whether the accounts are accurate.

templates.title: Executive Pay and Pay Multiple
templates.why: Residents should be able to see how senior pay compares to the lowest-paid staff and to peer councils.
templates.template:
Dear FOI Officer,

Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I request:

1. The Pay Policy Statement for 2025/26 (or the most recent version)
2. The total remuneration package for the Chief Executive, including salary, pension, bonuses, and benefits
3. The total remuneration for all officers earning over £50,000, listed by post title
4. The pay multiple ratio between the Chief Executive and the median employee earnings
5. The pay multiple ratio between the Chief Executive and the lowest-paid full-time equivalent
6. Any changes to senior officer pay or structure since April 2023
7. Benchmarking data used to set senior pay
templates.context: Councils are required to publish annual Pay Policy Statements under the Localism Act 2011, but these often lack the detail needed to fully understand senior pay arrangements.

categories.name: Services & Operations
categories.description: Questions about how well council services are performing

templates.title: Leisure Centre Costs and Strategy
templates.why: Pendle faces difficult decisions about leisure provision. Understanding the full financial picture helps residents engage with these decisions.
templates.template:
Dear FOI Officer,

Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I request:

1. The annual operating cost for each council-operated leisure centre for each year from 2021/22 to 2024/25
2. Annual visitor numbers for each leisure facility for the same period
3. Any condition surveys or structural assessments carried out in the last 5 years
4. The estimated cost of essential maintenance or repairs at each facility
5. Any feasibility studies or business cases for replacing, closing, or refurbishing facilities
6. The council's current Leisure Strategy document
7. Whether the council has explored partnerships with neighbouring authorities or the private sector
templates.context: Leisure centres are one of the most visible council services but also expensive to maintain. Ageing facilities require significant capital investment.

templates.title: Waste Collection and Disposal Costs
templates.why: Waste services cost approximately £2.6 million. Understanding the breakdown and comparisons with neighbours helps assess value for money.
templates.template:
Dear FOI Officer,

Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I request:

1. The total annual cost of waste collection for each year from 2021/22 to 2024/25
2. The total annual cost of waste disposal for the same period
3. A breakdown of disposal costs by waste stream
4. Current contract arrangements for waste collection and disposal
5. The cost per household for waste services and comparison with Lancashire averages
6. The council's implementation plan and cost estimate for mandatory food waste collection
7. The current recycling rate compared to national target and Lancashire average
8. Whether shared service arrangements with neighbouring authorities have been explored
templates.context: The introduction of mandatory food waste collection will add further costs. Understanding how Pendle's costs compare to neighbours helps assess value for money.

templates.title: Planning Department Costs and Performance
templates.why: Pendle has been reported as having some of the highest planning costs in the North West relative to applications processed.
templates.template:
Dear FOI Officer,

Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I request:

1. The total cost of the planning department for each year from 2021/22 to 2024/25
2. The number of planning applications received and determined for each year
3. The calculated cost per planning application determined
4. Total planning fee income received for each year
5. The percentage of applications determined within statutory timeframes
6. Any use of external planning consultants and their costs
7. Benchmarking data comparing Pendle's planning costs with other Lancashire districts
templates.context: An efficient planning service is essential for local economic growth. If the cost per application is significantly above peer averages, this may indicate inefficiency.

templates.title: Local Government Reorganisation Preparation Costs
templates.why: Lancashire is undergoing local government reorganisation. The transition costs should be transparent.
templates.template:
Dear FOI Officer,

Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I request:

1. The total amount spent on LGR preparations to date, broken down by category
2. A list of all external consultants or advisors engaged for LGR, including fees
3. Any budget allocated for LGR-related activity in 2025/26 and future years
4. How LGR costs are being funded — from reserves, existing budgets, or borrowing
5. Any impact assessments on how reorganisation may affect current services or staff
6. Copies of any submissions made to MHCLG regarding the preferred reorganisation option
templates.context: Local government reorganisation in Lancashire will replace the current two-tier system. The transition costs money during a period of significant financial pressure.

rights: Anyone can make an FOI request — you don't need to give a reason
The council must respond within 20 working days
Information should be free, though the council can charge for printing
If refused, you can request an internal review
If still unsatisfied, you can appeal to the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO)
tips: Be specific — vague requests are easier to refuse
Ask for documents, not opinions or explanations
Reference specific time periods (e.g. 'from April 2021 to March 2025')
If you know a specific document exists, ask for it by name
Keep requests focused on one topic for faster responses
